claim: A game engine does have a fuel injector.

supporting.text: A game engine is a software framework designed for video game development, not a mechanical device, so it cannot have physical components like a fuel injector.

attacks.text: A game engine is a software framework designed for video game development, not a mechanical device, so it cannot have physical components like a fuel injector.
Some game engines simulate physical components like fuel injectors for realism, even if they are not mechanical.
Simulated components are not equivalent to physical ones, so the claim remains false.

supporting.text: Fuel injectors are hardware components used in internal combustion engines to deliver fuel, which is irrelevant to the digital nature of a game engine.

attacks.text: Fuel injectors are hardware components used in internal combustion engines to deliver fuel, which is irrelevant to the digital nature of a game engine.
Some game engines simulate physical systems, including fuel injection, for realism in vehicle simulations.
Simulating fuel injection is not the same as having a physical fuel injector, which is what the claim implies.
The claim does not specify whether it refers to physical or simulated components, leaving room for interpretation.

supporting.text: Game engines handle rendering, physics, and scripting, none of which involve fuel injection or combustion processes.

attacks.text: Game engines handle rendering, physics, and scripting, none of which involve fuel injection or combustion processes.
Some game engines simulate vehicle systems, including fuel injection, for realism in driving games.
Simulating fuel injection is not the same as having a physical fuel injector; it's just a software model.
Certain specialized game engines integrate with hardware systems for industrial training, which may include actual fuel injectors.

supporting.text: The term 'engine' in 'game engine' is metaphorical, referring to its role as a core system for game functionality, not as a mechanical power source.

attacks.text: The term 'engine' in 'game engine' is metaphorical, referring to its role as a core system for game functionality, not as a mechanical power source.
Some game engines, like those used in vehicle simulations, may include mechanical component modeling, potentially including fuel injectors.
Even in vehicle simulations, the fuel injector would be a simulated component, not a physical part of the game engine software itself.
The word 'engine' can have multiple meanings, and in technical contexts, the interpretation might not always be purely metaphorical.
In all documented uses of 'game engine' in industry and academia, it exclusively refers to software systems, never to physical components.
